Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Integrating roots into whole plant phenotypes: ecological and genetic perturbations
Award.AbstractNarration: Complex plant phenotypes are influenced by the environment, genetics and their interactions. The root system has been largely overlooked in natural or ecologically relevant settings in the plant species Arabidopsis thaliana. An overarching goal of this project is to examine in Arabidopsis thaliana how traits and their relationships within the root, within the shoot, and between the root and shoot change across habitats in nature. In this project, natural variation of root traits and soil nutrient features in field populations will be examined and plants will be grown in varying natural ecological settings. Genetic tools will be employed to examine the effects of the disruption of single genes on root traits and their relationships with shoot traits. These data will form the largest ecological dataset for Arabidopsis roots in the field. Roots are critical to successful agriculture and may have positive or negative relationships with other agriculturally important traits. These data will therefore inform agricultural scientists on how root traits, shoot traits, and trait relationships change across environments and with genetic perturbations. This project will engage a diverse group of undergraduate students in the study of whole plant phenotypes as research apprentices, in classroom inquiry based learning, and through service learning experiences to the urban kindergarten community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How do roots vary across natural environments? Do roots of populations from particular ecological settings maintain their root structure when grown in new environments? Are specific genes particularly influential on changes in root traits across environments? To address these questions, we examined wild populations of plants across years in natural and garden settings. We also implemented experiments using seeds of single-gene mutants in the widely studied genetic model plant species Arabidopsis thaliana.

 

In this National Science Foundation funded project, plants were excavated and studied for aboveground and belowground traits. We examined plants for variation in critical vigor traits such as size at initiation of flowering and fruit production, as well as root traits such as total root length. From wild populations, nearly 1300 plants were studied and data on nearly 30 associated soil and ecological characteristics were collected. In garden experiments in the native and non-native range across two years, we studied 8500 plants for survival, root and shoot characteristics. In greenhouse experiments with mutant lines and wild populations, plants were measured for over 20 aboveground and belowground traits on over 4000 plants. In the greenhouse genetic knockout experiments, soil variation experienced in the wild was mimicked, and data will be made publically available at arabidopsisunpak.org. We uncovered new genes involved in plant root traits and response to environments. Ecological soil conditions were more influential than seedling traits in predicting root and shoot performance in field and greenhouse settings.

 

Providing the next generation of biology scholars with hands on learning opportunities was central to this project. Research apprentices travelled to field sites, conducted greenhouse and garden experiments, contributed to trait measurements and digital imaging and analysis, and co-authored manuscripts. Over 20 students participated in the project as research apprentices, gaining training in biological protocols, data management, data display, and scientific communication. Students and faculty brought new ecological and plant science hands-on activities to local urban elementary schools and a public library as well as on campus STEM events engaging K-8 students from throughout the region. Each semester, additional undergraduate students gained experience in research through CURE (Course based Undergraduate Research Experience) in college classes by studying variation in plants in response to ecologically relevant environmental conditions.
